reviewText: I don't quite remember what drove me to the Sient Hunter series. I think I saw them on Steam one day and thought to myself hey cool
date: submarines!". Before that moment I had very little interest in the subject and even less knowlege. To my understanding: a submarine was just a boat that traveled over and under water with a periscope for looking around. I know now that they are so much more than that.\n\nA submarine is a complicated piece of machinery that is designed to stealthily ambush enemy merchant ships. They are no match for destroyers and dive bombers are a constant nightmare. Above water
hoursPlayed: they are sitting ducks. Underwater they are blind as bats
voteText: with only sound to guide their eyes. Most of your torpedoes will be duds
helpfulPercent:
and if enemy war ships become aware of your presence your only hope is to submerge and leave the area quickly; and pray that the depth charges don't sink your boat.

There is a reason why German u-boats were called "iron coffins". It's because they had the highest casualty rate during WW2.

In Silent Hunter 4 (wolves of the pacific) you get to play on the American side as a submariner in the pacific theater of the war. With the U-boat Missions addon you can play the German side in the same theater. That expansion updates the game to 1.5
votesHelpful: so it is required in order to use a lot of the mods for the game. There is one mod in particular that expands the default German campaign into the Atlantic and North Sea areas; definitely a must if you prefer that side of the conflict. Or just get Silent Hunter 2
votesFunny: or 5 (all u-boat games). Silent Hunter 4 is unique because it's the first game since Silent Hunter 1 that lets players command American subs. Unfortunately Japanese subs are not playable
commentsCount: which would have been a huge bonus.\n\nI think the general consensus of this game is: you will either love it or hate it. I've seen people putting the game down either for some annoying bugs (and they are annoying) or simply because they don't prefer the submarine warfare in the Pacific theater. Personally
column16: I like it. The American subs are unique in their own way
column17: but not completely different from the German u-boats. The threat is still there
column18: but the Pacific Ocean is a vast place. You may find yourself traveling around for what seems an eternity before engaging in any type of action. To me
column19: this is the only drawback of the game. Most of the bugs and failings of the game can be improved with mods
column20: however; and there are plenty of them online.\n\nThe entire Silent Hunter series is great
column21: and every game in the list is a good submarine sim. If you are just looking for an arcade experience and want to jump right into the action
column22: then you can do that. However
column23: if you want an ultra-realistic simulator then turn up the realism settings and dive into the plethora of game-changing mods that are available online. This game is a great entry for anyone even remotely interested in the subject. You won't learn everything about submarine life
column24: but you will walk away with a new found appreciation for it!"

reviewText:
A+

I have played Silent Hunter 4 more than any other game on Steam. I was obsessed with it, played it every waking hour. Read up on Submarines. Watched the six-hour cut of Das Boot twice.

I would describe it to non-submarine nerds as a slow-paced stealth game. Very methodical. You can even calculate the trajectories for your torpedoes yourself, in what becomes perhaps the most compelling educational math game of all time. The game is very narrative, and open world in nature, though said world is almost entirely endless sea. I have hounded Japanese ships off the coast of Alaska, hiding in the fog as I used hit-and-run tactics against no fewer than five enemy destroyers, ever wary of their lumbering shadows in the mist. I have stalked convoys for days on end, slowly whittling down their numbers. I have used daring tactics to great success, narrowly avoiding the avalanche of depth charges from the surface. And I have used safe, time-tested strategies only to find myself sliding into a watery grave.

The game is tight as ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: It's not for everyone I must say, at first I was rather turned off by the lack of any true tutorial but as you get a feel for the controls the game truly shines as you sneak into the middle of the Japanese fleet heading to capture midway that you painstakingly search the pacific for, line up the perfect shot with a steam powered no wake torpedo in tub 3 and 4 waiting for the perfect moment and then FIRE!  You're waiting tensley as the seconds tick by into minutes and then as despair comes to your heart and you are about to call the order to dive and head back to base you see the first then second plume of water rise into the air over the enemy carrier.  You smile to yourself lower periscope and dive below the thermal layer to make sure destroyers won't find you as you head back to singapore.  This is a game that really does reward the patient, there's satifaction in setting up that shot and hitting exactly where you wanted to.

reviewText:
This game has a lot to offer for just $10.

The game includes the following features:

Multiple controllable submarines of different sizes, capabilities, crew count and more.

A huge amount of ships both enemy and friendly.

Enemy threats not only include ships but also reconnaissance and attack aircraft of varying
types that pose a massive danger if surfaced.

You can play many roles (sonar & radar operator, navigator, captain, gun operators (deckgun,
AAA gun), torpedo tube operator, etc..)

The game allows you to organize your crew to specific tasks based on their experience; if
some crew members are sleeping you can assign any other crew member their to position,
same thing if they're wounded.

Ability to prioritize what problems are being dealt with (i.e. damaged bulkhead, periscope,
etc..) by the crew and situation.

Real-time gameplay with the ability to fast forward as much as you like (not always the best
idea to go too fast)

The game looks fantastic and is not very demanding at all.

Ability to travel the entire Pacific and possibly further (never tried).

Destroying enemy merchants, naval vessels, aircraft and such can be very rewarding
especially when you are on a patrol. The game automatically writes logs of time date and
location of neutralization of enemy activity.

Game has a few different types of missions including rescue missions in enemy waters,
searching to destroy specific vessels, war patrols, support missions and much more.


This game can bring hours of slow paced and intense experiences if you play it right.

The game is not hard as long  as you know what you're doing. I highly recommend looking up some
tutorials on Youtube and Google right away because the game's tutorial isn't very good to be
honest. Once you accomplish that the game will make a lot more sense and you'll have a lot more
fun and struggle much less.

The game goes on sale often, but right now at $10 it is completely worth it.

reviewText:
Very GOOD !!!

I never thought a submarine simulator was so cool! And never thought it would be so hard to hit a 200m ship with a torpedo!

One day I was on a mission off the coast of Hokkaido (the northern island of Japan) I saw two destroyers, was lining up to shoot the torpedo when suddenly I saw a light shining in the right corner of my periscope, turned about 30 ° and saw a another destroyer 200m coming towards me, immediately made a Crash Dive and began to rain several deep cartoons at the end survived.

Never thought it would be so exciting!

I recommend to all who love simulators!

reviewText: While it lacks the slick GUI of Silent Hunter 3, Wolves of the Pacific offers up more of that awesome addictive tension that Silent Hunter 3 offers and does so in a pretty package. However, the disparity between vessels, I find, to be not as great as it was in 3. While you've got your very fun low end subs like the S-Boats, you don't have the awesome death-incarnate murder machines like the Type XXI. The Balao is great, but what I'm getting at here is that you don't see the same disparity of performance that you saw in Silent Hunter 3. This is a minor gripe, either way. This game is still well worth a purchase.

reviewText:
I'm very dissapointed by this game. SH3 had it's bugs, but at least it was playable. SH4 has more bugs than Florida swamps. Don't buy it, you'll only get frustrated. There have allegedly been 3 patches, but to no effect.

When your sub gets damaged, team will randomly decide not to repair it. Which will result in you sink to the bottom of shallow Japanese sea. On other ocassion, damage control team will not repair sub based on your list of priorities to fix. For example, you have flooding, they will continue to repair other stuff, which will again result in you being a nice addition to bottom of the sea.

When you try to shoot AA gun, in some positions you will not be able to see coming plane, because your view is how you turn your gun, behind metal fence of conning tower. So you aim your AA gun through steel wall, and it's best to leave it to the crew, which is lousy shoot FYI.

First mission in American Career, extreme stupidity. You complete main objective (photo recon of Hiroshima port) and game will not let you know if you're done or not? You sink ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of their warships and merchants, still you're not done. You try to exit map, mission failed.

And a little thing to mention is that you have to choose sub type on start of career. So you decide to go with sub that has range of 11.000 km, stationed in Pearl Harbour. First mission, do photo recon of Hiroshima port, which is 8.500 km from your home port. In short, you will probably be on very tight schedule with diesel. You think, ok, I'll take it slowly, try to use electric engine even when out on open see and no enemies, but when you start game, you discover, ♥♥♥♥, there's not command to your crew to calculate range at speed"
recommended: you don't know what is your fuel consumption and will you be able to get to home port at all. Well

reviewText: First of all, it would be a F-ing awesome game... IF YOU'D KNOW HOW TO PLAY IT, the 'training' isn't usefull at all, they just put you on a mission and except you to know how to do it, for example, if you choose the navigation training, you just spawn in middle of an ocean with a objective, and that's it. They don't introduce you how to control your Sub at all, they just expect you to learn it yourself. Usually learning yourself is the best way, BUT not here, because there's too many things to learn, it's just impossible. It's hard to sink a ship with torpedoes since your Submarine won't want to agree to turn towards the ship, it's always too late to turn since you've already gone past the ship you're supposed to sink. That's about it, this can be a awesome game, IF i knew how to play it, it does look good, there are alot of different ships, many nations. Even Merchant ships. But it just won't work when i can't control my Sub properly. The AA guns on the deck is easy to use tho, the aiming is kinda bad and zooming in doens't help almost at all, but it still is easy to shoot down enemy Planes. This game has pros and cons, but if it had proper tutorial to navigation and other stuff, I'd most likely love this game.

reviewText:
I like this game overall but have had a few growing pains with it. One thing that bothers me is that Wolves of the Pacific is only patched to 1.4. In order to get the 1.5 patch, Ubisoft makes you buy the U-boat addon. That is just a money grab. If I wanted to play U-boats I would fall back to SH3.

At first I thought that the stock game had way to many airplane attacks in career mode. Once I got SD radar, the airplanes are a non factor. The TDC behaves differently in US fleet boats than in German U-boats from SH3. This is modeled well in SH4 to reflect the historic differences in subs.

Overall SH4 is as good as SH3 with one major improvement. SH3 saves did not always load while I have had no trouble loading career saves from SH4.  Generally the seas seam to calm too often. 75% of the time the Pacific has only 2 to 3 ffot waves. Also the Deck gun can easily account for 50 plus tons of sunk ships which is way unrealistic. I did some research of the USS-Drum. That sub was 8th all time in tonnage sunk by a US sub during WWII. It suck approximately 85,000 tons of ships over 13 missions. You can do that in one mission in stock SH4 at 100% realism.

Needless to say I have modded a few things. Namely, reduced shells for most deck guns from 120 to 24. Otherwise the game is so easy it isn't even fun. I also made it more likely to have dud torpedoes early in the war.

Be sure to sheck out the mods available at subsim.

reviewText: I have played this game for a long time outside of steam (about 140 hours logged) and I have nothing bad to say about it. It kinda sucks how steam doesn't give you the right version, but that's a steam problem, not a game problem. If possible, buy the game outside of steam. The community for this series is still really active and there are a lot of great mods out there for it. Multiplayer is a blast, though you'll have to find some people to play through LAN because the multiplayer servers are non-existant.\n\nOverall, great game, challenging and realistic sim. Avoid the 5th one.

reviewText:
This is my favourite of the Silent Hunter games.

The gameplay is fun and the realism can be tweaked around to your liking.
And it's very responsive and very entertaining.
Plus it proves a very good Challenge.

And you can just pick small missions if you want to.

The grapichs still looks good and you can see on what have been focused on.
It's not a bad looking game

The story is not focused alot in this game, but are in the game and are shown through mission briefings
that more or likely are based on history facts.

Thank god for the speed up button.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. No, really. Back to the days of commanding a B-17 squadron, but this time, a Submarine for the US Navy in the Pacific. My first encounter did take sometime. One hour to even find anything, but when I did, I wasn't letting him get away. A Japanese Destroyer, I didn't even check what class from the handy ship encyclopedia they give you for ID'ing ship classes and faction ownership.

There was a problem though... it was faster than me! I wasn't letting it escape, so I surfaced, manned the gun and fired at it like. 'Yeah! You! Come and fight!' Needless to say, they did. Unfortunately for them, I was a lot more accurate. I hit him twice, causing two fires on his outer section. When he came straight for me, I dived and evaded. It was then he made the fatal mistake of turning east. I had escaped to the West and cut my engines. Twenty minutes passed as I kept a low profile, watching it limp around, looking for me in all the wrong places, but then.... *woosh* 'Torpedo in the water.' ....and another... He tried to turn, cut his speed, but it was too late and my shots were true. A massive explosion rocked the aft of the Japanese destroyer, causing it to slump into the Pacific ocean. The second, smashed into the front, at first, apparently causing little damage, however fifteen seconds later, she was submerged and rolled into a watery grave. A massive explosion erupted a large wave into the air several moments after she went under with all hands on board.



Love it. Learned a lot from my first encounter, and have a lot more to learn. Bring it on!

reviewText:
I give this game a 6.5/10.

PROS: As my only Submarine simulator in my inventory, I will say my first impressions with this game were very good.  I got hooked on sailing the pacific ocean, stalking my enemy before destroying their ships and forcing them to the bottom of the sea.  Learning how to use the crew, their watch schedule and rotation, and watching them get promoted and recieve awards for their actions was the most satisfying part of this game for me.  Each submarine performs differently and the missions you recieve can have very tense moments that had me sweating.

CONS: This game is not very well optimized and using time acceleration can be very dangerous as enemy ships and planes will appear of out no where and sink your ship. Also, after hours of gameplay all of my save files suddenly became corrupt and I am completely unable to play the game now. I would look into what went wrong, but I am playing other games now.

If the game had been fixed at some point during it's life then I have no doubt it would be one of the best Submarine games on the market.

If you are interested in this game, buy it when it is on sale and have fun. Just be warned that there are many problems that may make your experience aggravating.

reviewText: The last great Silent Hunter game made. Different from the greatness of Silent Hunter 3, by being in the pacific and on a U.S. submarine. Until the Uboat missions came out and you use a Type IX (9) series U-boat, and in. June 1944, you can opt to get one of the XXI Type 21 Elektroboots. Which never existed except for a few prototypes which uses the legendary Walter Turbine. With it and being chased by an escort you can easily change depth so quickly with it underwater my submarine will run at 26 knots underwater. On the surface in good weather 35-38 knots using the walter turbine.

reviewText:
WINDOWS 8 & 10, READ THIS!!!

This game WILL NOT run on your PC unless you follow these steps.

1. Find sh4.exe in the steam/steamapps/silent hunter wolves of the pacific" folder
2. Right click
date: and select properties\n3. Run enable compaitibility
recommended:
with xp service pack 3
4. Enable "Disable display scaling on high dpi settings"

Now run the game from either the .exe or steam launcher.

Great game

reviewText: HI so I played this game on and off for a few hours, and I have to say, dispite some minor bugs here and there, Communities are very efficient at modding and after getting my mods working, well, mods are key to this game, without them like Trigger Maru" it's impossible to enjoy.  I have to say communities still rock for Silent Hunter Wolves of the Pacific
date: there still needs some more "Polishing" mods out there
recommended: but with the overhaul called Trigger Maru
hoursPlayed: it makes it so much more fun than the normal issues lag when huge fleets like 60+ ships appearing and the like."
voteText: April 11

reviewText: First off, this game is not for everyone. It has no waifus, no real impressive graphics (aside from very pretty water even nearly a decade later) and requires mods and its expansion to really provide an immersive experience. But even Vanilla, the game is a blast. It's hard to recreate the tension I get out of this game, especially when you're really into it. It also focuses on an aspect of World War II usually forgotten by the general public in favor of the more flashy and decisive land battles in the European Theater, or the large scale naval engagements in the South Pacific - the devistating and heroic actions of the men of the Silent Service, the USN's Submariners. And even they are left often ignored, the focus on their German counterparts in the Atlantic instead. When this game gets into you, when you get into that mindset of the wolf amongst the waves, it offers an experience I can say no other game has offered me.
